ef:EnvironmentalMonitoringFacility.ef:name: Lago Maggiore
ef:EnvironmentalMonitoringFacility.ef:additionalDescription: Lake Maggiore was studied since the beginning of last century although not systematically. Regular researches started by the foundation in 1938 of the Italian Institute of Hydrobiology "Dr. Marco De Marchi" located in Verbania Pallanza. Early studies, directed in particular to zoo and phytoplankton taxonomy and ecology, were rapidly flanked by research on the chemistry and physics of lake and on the meteorological conditions affecting it. In fact since 1952 comes into operation a limnographic (level and temperature profile) and weather station that remained active ever since. Studies on plankton and on hydrochemistry of Lake Maggiore continued between the years 50 and 70 of the last century, highlighting the progressive eutrophication. Thanks also to the research of the institute, in the 80 effective actions to control the eutrophication were undertaken, with the large-scale activation of waste water treatment plants. In 1980 started a program, still active, of systematic monitoring and research sponsored by CIPAIS (International Commission for the Protection of the Italian Swiss Waters) which allowed to collect an uninterrupted and long time series, with high sampling frequency, of data related to meteorology, hydrology, physic and chemistry of the lake, organic carbon and bacterial populations, phyto-and zooplankton. The analysis of these time series have shown a gradual decline, from 1980 to present,of phosphorus input and of P in-lake concentration. This decrease was accompanied by a progressive reduction in the concentration of chlorophyll, of algal bimass and of organic carbon in the lake, starting the oligotrophication process leding to the current state of oligotrophy of Lake Maggiore, that is the typical trophic condition for this environment. The study of the lake temperatures has also highlighted the effect of global warming on Lake Maggiore, which went towards the gradual warming of deep hypolimnion as well as the raising of the average temperature of the surface layers. The availability of the time series mentioned above will be useful to identify the long-term ecological effects of this phenomenon.
